awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Uncovering the role of Golgi organization on function
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic cell engineering has the potential to reveal insights into the fundamental chemical and physical processes that underlie the function of biological cells and organelles as well as advance the design of biologically-inspired devices and materials with applications ranging from medicine to biotechnology. Recently, it has become clear that the function of many proteins and lipids in biological cells depends on posttranslational modifications, covalent additions to the surface of proteins after their synthesis. A majority of these modifications are performed by the Golgi apparatus, a central membrane organelle in mammalian cells with a unique and dynamically changing structure. Yet neither the features of the Golgi that facilitate the synthesis of these highly complex chemical structures nor how those reactions are spatially and temporally controlled is fully understood. To better understand the regulatory mechanisms of the Golgi structure, this proposal will reconstitute chemical and physical features of the Golgi in an in vitro system. 

This proposal will develop new strategies to uncover how physical features of membranes influence an essential posttranslational modification, glycosylation. Specifically, it will recreate a model multi-step glycosylation modification of lipid carriers in vitro using both microfluidic and vesicle-based platforms and uncover the rules of membrane spatial and physical features required to recapitulate the posttranslational modification process. Successful completion of these studies will reveal design rules that will enable creation of other posttranslational modifications through re-organization of these reactions, including synthetic modifications. With these insights, it will be possible to extend these findings to influence the activity and function of modified proteins and lipids in order to impact biological processes. This project will bridge a variety of interdisciplinary techniques in membrane biophysics, membrane protein reconstitution, protein engineering, microfluidics, transport phenomena, and chemical kinetics necessary to realize the project goals. The knowledge developed here will benefit the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries and have potential biomanufacturing applications in the design of therapeutic compounds. 

This project is jointly funded by the Cellular Dynamics and Function and Systems and Synthetic Biology Clusters, Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, Directorate for Biological Sciences and by the Cellular and Biochemical Engineering Program, Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems, Directorate for Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the rules of life necessary to build synthetic cells that recapitulate processes of living organisms is a promising, emerging field that could ultimately define what it means to “be alive” and enable control of life in unprecedented ways that can benefit mankind. Achieving this knowledge will require understanding how to synthesize some of the basic biological building blocks of living cells and how specific organelles work. Of particular interest to this project is the Golgi apparatus, an organelle that precisely builds glycans for the posttranslational modification (PTM) of proteins and glycolipid modification to regulate cellular processes. Yet neither the features of the Golgi that facilitate the synthesis of these highly complex chemical structures nor how those reactions are spatially and temporally controlled is fully understood.

The overall objective of this project is to gain this critical understanding of this organelle, by deconstructing it into in vitro systems that allow testing of the constraints of modularity, sequence, and spatial arrangement of the proteins that enable and carry out glycosylation and drive this major PTM function of the Golgi. During this work, we successfully adapted a process to create cell-free proteins and glycans using biomembrane devices and vesicles, which were subsequently used to test their function and activity. We created a synthetic ER-Golgi system that allowed us to define the relationships between enzyme spatial arrangement, membrane physical features, and efficiency of model processes to manufacture proteins and glycans. We have found that spatio-temporal control of reactions matters to the final product.

Intellectual Merit. This project recreated a model multi-step glycosylation modification of lipid carriers in vitro and uncovered rules of membrane spatial and physical features required to recapitulate the PTM process. Successful completion of these studies revealed design rules that enable the cell-free production of functional proteins and glycans. With these insights, it is possible to rebuild defined biochemical pathways into cell-compatible compartments. In the future, it may be possible that these structures could be implanted into biological or synthetic cells to engender the cell with the ability to create biochemical processes that may have novel activities and control over cellular processes. This work advanced efforts aimed at creating a synthetic cell with integrated synthetic organelles that may engender them with new and unique capabilities.

Broader Impacts. The fundamental knowledge gained during this project provides critical insight into the biology of the Golgi apparatus and its dependence on its organization. The knowledge developed here benefits the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries and has potential applications in the design of therapeutic compounds.  Understanding the role of organelles and their physical properties in contributing to the biochemical efficiency of a biological cell is paramount to being able to re-create it artificially with synthetic components. This project revealed fundamental aspects of protein synthesis and activity for a few model systems, but opens the possibility of revealing aspects of protein function that may apply to all membrane-associated proteins. Such information has the potential to extend our knowledge outside of the Golgi apparatus. During this project, students fostered the next generation of high school students following STEM fields and becoming excited about synthetic biology careers through outreach activities that engage K-12 girls and their parents.  

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2024
Modified by: Susan Daniel
